parts.title: Introduction to Futures Thinking
parts.body: Phil Balagtas introduces Futures Thinking in "Making Futures Work" by exploring humanity's historical fascination with predicting the future. Throughout history, prophets or soothsayers were considered early "futurists," revealing premonitions using patterns, similar to today's strategic foresight approaches. Balagtas emphasizes our inherent ability to speculate about the future for survival and progress, highlighting tools used in Futures Thinking. The book starts by depicting how futures can be deconstructed and navigated, akin to a metaphorical device in uncertain times, reinforcing our pursuit for survival.

parts.title: Embracing Speculative Futures and Navigating Uncertainty
parts.body: Even with advanced sensors and algorithms, speculation about the future remains a necessary practice, albeit one with a level of uncertainty. Just like weather predictions, our journey into the future involves preparing for uncertainties (like taking an umbrella for unexpected rain). Embracing Futures Thinking helps us navigate the unknown, using our senses to comprehend patterns for successful navigation. Embracing the mantra "Fail we may, sail we must", we pursue futurism much like early humans documented their world—by learning from past patterns and enhancing foresight.

parts.title: Preparing for Futures Work
parts.body: The initial stage before engaging in futures work, called Stage 0, involves understanding your audience, assessing the future mindset, and effectively framing the problem and project. It includes preparing for futures projects by gathering necessary information about the team, client, organization, and problem space. This understanding helps avoid confusion later when generating content and possibilities. Stage 0 includes: - Understanding the projects, people, and environment. - Implementing methods for understanding audience and determining project *design*. - Preparing clients or teams for the journey by showing them examples and explaining the process. - Ensuring alignment and excitement for the upcoming work by setting up the right team, timeline, deliverables, and logistics. It's crucial for preparing the tools, repositories, and processes for the journey. - Framing the detailed project parameters like focal issue, time horizon, and geographic boundaries.

parts.title: Understanding Future Needs and Situational Awareness
parts.body: Futuring requires understanding your audience by employing traditional inquiry methods. Use interviews or workshops to gather essential information from your "passengers," i.e., clients. By asking questions and diagnosing their current state—similar to diagnosing a situation in aviation with situational awareness (SA)—you anticipate potential challenges and opportunities. Questions should include why the audience is interested in the future, the nature of the project, and how they currently manage strategies. This initial understanding or "diagnostic" phase is key to preparing for the journey ahead.

parts.title: Using Canvases and Causal Layered Analysis (CLA)
parts.body: Using canvases is a great way to understand deeper details of a business, exposing interdependencies, strengths, weaknesses, and opportunities within a system. Canvases are flexible and can categorize your needs, but be cautious—they could require more time, expose sensitive info, oversimplify complexities, and lead to analysis paralysis. Causal Layered Analysis (CLA) helps unravel the deep-rooted systemic pillars influencing current perceptions through a structured layered approach: litany, causes, worldview, and myths/metaphors. It can uncover the cultural myths driving opinions, but needs time and an experienced facilitator for honest and direct insights, potentially leading to important future transformations.

parts.title: Pushing Audience towards Innovative Ideas
parts.body: In Futures Thinking, it's important to determine how far you can push your audience with innovative ideas. Some companies want to be disruptive but might be risk-averse due to their organizational culture or top-down constraints. Using the right examples is key to shaping a company's vision of the future, but you have to carefully gauge your audience's openness to provocative ideas through a diagnostic process. Successful futures projects can inspire innovation by sailing into exciting new territories if the audience is ready for it. For instance, a vision video by GE Transportation used emerging technologies like virtual reality to map a 10-year plan for their freight division, showcasing practical applications of futures concepts.

parts.title: Framing a Project
parts.body: Framing a Project involves setting logistics and parameters which guide a futures project. Every organization might have its unique way of organizing timelines and activities, but it's important to keep efforts organized. As the project lead, you will need to manage aspects like timeline, budget, and securing a supportive team. By doing this, you ensure you are directing and delivering the outputs and assets produced throughout the process. When managing a project, consider aspects like planning key activities, knowing the project timeline, securing allies, aligning on deliverables, setting up workspaces for collaboration, and determining success metrics. Each of these components contributes to a structured approach that helps keep the project focused and on track. Being well-prepared helps to avoid issues during execution and makes the journey through project tasks efficient and effective.

parts.title: Exploring Strategic Foresight and World Building
parts.body: In Strategic Foresight, primary and secondary research tactics are used to learn about the problem space and foresee signals of change. These could be patterns like trends (widely adopted shifts) or emerging technologies. Unlike traditional design research, Strategic Foresight isn't about solving immediate problems but rather understanding potential future scenarios. Critics question the value of foresight, arguing current issues should be prioritized, but foresight advocates claim it allows for proactive long-term planning, which can also help address today's challenges by developing informed perspectives and strategies. The World Building process in Strategic Foresight constructs possible future worlds to visualize scenarios. This mirrors how literature creates entire worlds for readers. Through these constructed worlds—histories, laws, cultures, and actors—future potentials, including dystopian or transformative scenarios, can be imagined. Exploring these worlds helps designers and strategists understand how to best operate within them and prepares them to envision future product and service designs today. Like building a belief system, world building helps in navigating future uncertainties by fostering a mindset open to exploring and creating potential future environments.

parts.title: Understanding Trends, Drivers, and Signals
parts.body: Trends, drivers, and signals are key elements in understanding how patterns form and evolve. Designers often take on the role of anthropologists by conducting interviews and gathering contextual information to look for root causes of problems. By doing so, they ensure they are addressing the right issue at its source. A trend is seen when small repeated events accumulate over time, revealing a noticeable pattern. Trends aren't isolated; they are the result of underlying drivers. These drivers show up as signals, which collectively form a trend. For instance, in the tech industry, generative AI tools stem from drivers like speed, LLMs, and fidelity of output. It’s important to explore the driver rather than just the surface trend, as this helps prevent repeating the same issues elsewhere.

parts.title: Using Narratives and Images for Future Scenarios
parts.body: Narratives have become popular for describing future scenarios through formats like day-to-day life stories or environmental descriptions. An example is Arup's 2050 Scenarios report comprising four divergent futures, one being Greentocracy where global climate efforts lead to sacrifices by people under "happy planet, happy people." Using narratives can integrate multiple aspects and can be cost-effective, but may lack impact without supporting visuals. Illustrations can enhance narratives by providing visual context, which may help in stimulating discussions or marketing. Yet, they risk being overwhelming or underwhelming depending on detail.

parts.title: Scenario Planning and Axes of Uncertainty
parts.body:
Scenario Planning and Future Thinking

When creating user interfaces, it's crucial to think about "what if?" scenarios. Understanding these can help build systems that handle errors and prevent inconvenience or harm to users. This approach is similar in scenario planning, where some scenarios are more likely to occur, needing comprehensive responses, while others are less probable, requiring simpler considerations. By examining various scenarios, like expected ocean storms, businesses can better prepare for future challenges.

Axes of Uncertainty

Given the unpredictability of the future, using tools like the Axes of Uncertainty helps in evaluating different outcomes. By plotting topics in a 2x2 matrix, one can understand potential oppositions and similarities, aiding in the development of richer scenarios. While the axes can appear narrow, it's a useful starting point to plot contrasting ideas and outcomes. However, for extensive scenario development, multiple axes might be needed as they offer varied perspectives on the future's unpredictability.

parts.title: Design's Role in Futures Thinking
parts.body: Design plays a key role in Futures Thinking, providing holistic insights into potential future evolutions of products and services. The growing convergence of Strategic Foresight, Futures Studies, and Design is expanding the role of Design in this field. Design can enhance futures work through discovering insights, synthesizing information, and rapid prototyping. It uses tools from various disciplines like systems thinking, service design, anthropology, and social sciences to navigate futures, be it for the immediate tomorrow or a far-off future. Thus, designers are becoming increasingly integral to foresight projects due to their ability to visualize and create innovative outcomes that serve as strategic visions or North Stars for organizations.

parts.title: Lowe's Innovation Labs: Sci-Fi Prototyping into Real-World Solutions
parts.body: Lowe's Innovation Labs use Sci-Fi Prototyping to address challenges today and in the future. Through a blend of storytelling, emerging technology, and user research, they turn speculative stories into real-world innovations like in-store robots and visualizations. This process leverages comics as an initial step to discuss what's relevant to Lowe's employees and customers. Ultimately, it combines the imagined future with present needs to lead to impactful innovations. The labs showcase how story-driven innovation involves crafting an emotional narrative to explore new tech applications while also conducting physical or virtual prototyping. This holistic approach helps generate not only concrete results but also new intellectual property. Here, the focus is on harmonizing various elements to pave the way for a structured approach to innovation that aligns with human and market needs.

parts.title: Crafting Effective Ideation Workshops
parts.body: The provided text explores the concept of crafting ideation workshops for futures thinking, using a foresight-driven approach. Establishing clear preparation is vital, whether by setting expectations for participants, designing engaging ideation experiences, or selecting the appropriate methods for creative output. Inputs like research artifacts and immersive exercises are essential to align participants' mindset with future contexts effectively. Techniques such as rapid ideation, narrative prompts, or immersive experiences can stimulate diverse outcomes, while being open to iteration is suggested for refinement and depth.

parts.title: NORMALS' Fictional Relocation Agency for Mexico City
parts.body: In 2017, NORMALS was invited to Mexico City by LabCDMX to envision the future of Xochimilco neighborhood. As part of this project, they introduced a fictional relocation agency named CDRMX. This agency aimed to combine 3D-printed housing and universal income to address potential relocation needs in the area. Through engaging events like lectures and workshops, participants were immersed in this envisioned future, significantly enhanced by fictional storytelling from individuals like Régis Lemberthe, who played an economist in this narrative. Part of the envisioned architectural program involved the creation of low-res 3D-printed housing. This initiative sought to preserve both neighborhood history and personal stories by capturing architectural textures and reliefs for reprinting in newly built districts. However, due to the limitations of low-resolution scanning, a new kind of low-definition architectural aesthetics emerged. The project aimed not only at practical solutions but also at sparking discussions on aesthetics and the preservation of history in an evolving urban landscape.

parts.title: Integrating Futures Thinking Strategy
parts.body: Incorporating Futures Thinking into an organization requires thoughtful planning and approach. Understanding organizational culture is crucial before advocating for new practices. Whether you're an insider or an outsider, every organization has its own cultural and operational nuances that influence how new initiatives are accepted. Establishing a futures mindset involves treating it like a campaign, which means committing to dedication, patience, and developing a comprehensive strategy. If you're introducing Futures Thinking from the inside, be mindful of your organization's existing processes and politics, even when stepping into teams that already employ some futures practices. It's vital not to disrupt current methodologies or people. Building institutional buy-in starts with informative groundwork and creating supportive environments. Proper research, planning, and experimentation can help in establishing futures thinking, though the journey can be lonely and protracted initially.

parts.title: Introducing Futures Thinking at Work
parts.body: If you find yourself as the first to introduce Futures Thinking to your organization, explore various methods like delivering presentations, finding supporters or champions within the team, or using workshops and introduction tactics like the Trojan Horse concept (presenting Futures methods wrapped within a familiar approach). Additionally, inspiring examples such as IBM’s introduction of speculative design can guide strategy. Considerations involve potential alliance-forming, especially within strategic or innovative groups. Understanding the culture, leadership, and operational context is crucial for overcoming resistance or fostering acceptance.

parts.title: Integrating Futures into Organizations
parts.body: ## Future Integration into Organizations Incorporating Futures Thinking into organizations involves crafting a strategy that brings together insights from past, present, and future. Start by identifying goals and how you can guide the organization in understanding what has worked historically, what's driving current innovation, and what the future aspirations are. You can map out potential impacts of various approaches to strategizing, determining what success looks like and what happens if some efforts fail. The goal is to create a measurable value over the long term for stakeholders. Approaching this journey with belief in Futures Thinking can lead to significant rewards by transforming and adapting to changing landscapes, ultimately ensuring sustainable growth for your organization.
